comment: After Kasparov and Ponomariov used c2-c4 Anand used Nb1-c3, but Bf1-d3 (Kan Variation) , used by Ivanchuk in round 10 (he also followed with c2-c4 after he'd castled) , is supposed to be the "main line". White prepares to O-O and keeps open the option of c2-c4.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake made by Anand because it points out that he should have played Bf1-d3 to enter the Kan Variation, which is considered the "main line," instead of Nb1-c3.

context: This is a game between Adams, Michael (as White) and Ivanchuk, Vassily (as Black). Last move played: White plays Bishop to d3
reformulated: After Black played 10...Bf1-d3, a move known as the Kan Variation, it's considered suboptimal. This move diverges from the standard strategy of advancing to c4, which can lead to a more robust pawn structure. By opting for Bf1-d3, Black limits their central control and misses opportunities for a stronger queen's side play. White can continue with O-O, keeping options open for c2-c4, thereby maintaining central dominance and flexibility in their position.

comment: This is typical of a Paulsen Variation. Black leaves open his specific piece development and just uses pawn moves early-on to limit White's pieces. The down-side of this approach is that it's not very contentious and allows White to choose his set-up.
reasoning: The comment correctly explains the mistake made by the player, as it identifies the open nature of Black's piece development and the use of pawn moves that limit White's options.
